name.text: Finding the Surface Area of a Composite Solid

questiontext.text:
The figure below is a composite solid made up of a rectangular prism and a triangular prism joined together.

[[jsxgraph]] var board = JXG.JSXGraph.initBoard(divid, { boundingbox: [-5, 12, 30, -5], axis: false, showCopyright: false }); // Define points var A = board.create('point', [0, 0], {name: 'A', visible: false,fixed:true}); var B = board.create('point', [0, 6.2], {name: 'B', visible: false,fixed:true}); var C = board.create('point', [20, 6.2], {name: 'C', visible: false,fixed:true}); var D = board.create('point', [20, 0], {name: 'D', visible: false,fixed:true}); var E = board.create('point', [25, 3], {name: 'E', visible: false,fixed:true}); var F = board.create('point', [5, 3], {name: 'F', visible: false,fixed:true}); // Draw rectangle and triangle var rect = board.create('polygon', [A, B, C, D], {borders: {strokeColor: 'black'},fixed:true}); var triangle = board.create('polygon', [D, C, E], {borders: {strokeColor: 'black'},fixed:true}); // Draw diagonals board.create('line', [B, F], {dash: 2, straightFirst: false, straightLast: false,fixed:true}); board.create('line', [A, F], {dash: 2, straightFirst: false, straightLast: false,fixed:true}); board.create('line', [F, E], {dash: 2, straightFirst: false, straightLast: false,fixed:true}); // Add right-angle indicator at point A var RA1 = board.create('polygon', [ board.create('point', [0, 0], {visible: false ,fixed:true}), board.create('point', [0.8, 0.5], {visible: false,fixed:true}), board.create('point', [0.8, 1.2], {visible: false,fixed:true}), board.create('point', [0, 0.9], {visible: false,fixed:true}) ], { borders: {strokeColor: 'blue'}, fillColor: 'lightblue', highlight: false, withLines: true }); // Add right-angle indicator at point D (between 20 cm and 6 cm sides) var RA2 = board.create('polygon', [ board.create('point', [20, 0], {visible: false}), board.create('point', [20, 0.9], {visible: false}), board.create('point', [20.7, 1.1], {visible: false}), board.create('point', [20.7, 0.4], {visible: false}) ], { borders: {strokeColor: 'blue'}, fillColor: 'lightblue', highlight: false, withLines: true }); // Optional: label dimensions board.create('text', [-2, 4, '{#h#} cm'],{fixed:true}); board.create('text', [9, -1.1, '{#l#} cm'],{fixed:true}); board.create('text', [23, 1.5, '{#b#} cm'],{fixed:true}); [[/jsxgraph]]

  • The rectangular part has a height of \({@h@}\, \text{m}\) and a length of \({@l@}\, \text{m}\).
  • The triangular part is a right-angled triangle with a base of \({@b@}\, \text{m}\), a height of \({@h@}\, \text{m}\), and it shares the same width of \({@l@}\, \text{m}\) with the rectangular part.

  1. Calculate the total surface area of the rectangular part.

    \(\text{Area of the rectangular part} =\) [[input:ans1]] \(\text{m}^2\)

    [[feedback:prt1]]

  2. Calculate the total surface area of the triangular part.

    \(\text{Area of the triangular part} =\) [[input:ans2]] \(\text{m}^2\)

    [[feedback:prt2]]

  3. Calculate the total surface area of the solid.

    \(\text{Total surface area of the solid} =\) [[input:ans3]] \(\text{m}^2\)

    [[feedback:prt3]]

generalfeedback.text:
a. Calculate the total surface area of the rectangular part

There are three rectangular faces:

Rectangle 1 (bottom):
Area = \( {@l@} \times {@b@} = {@Rect_1@} \, \text{m}^2 \)

Rectangle 2 (side):
Area = \( {@l@} \times {@h@} = {@Rect_2@} \, \text{m}^2 \)

Rectangle 3 (slanted side):
First, find the hypotenuse of the triangle:
\( c = \sqrt{{@b@}^2 + {@h@}^2} = \sqrt{{@b_2@} + {@h_2@}} = \sqrt{@squared@} = {@hyp@} \, \text{m} \)
Area = \( {@l@} \times {@hyp@} = {@Rect_3@} \, \text{m}^2 \)

Total surface area of rectangular part = \( 1{@Rect_1@}+ {@Rect_2@} + {@Rect_3@}= \boxed{{@rect_area@} \, \text{m}^2} \)

b. Calculate the total surface area of the triangular part

Each triangular base:
Area = \( \frac{1}{2} \times {@b@} \times {@h@} = {@Tri_1@} \, \text{m}^2 \)

Total surface area of triangular part = \( 2 \times {@Tri_1@} = \boxed{{@tri_area @} \, \text{m}^2} \)

c. Calculate the total surface area of the solid

Total surface area = \( {@rect_area@} + {@tri_area @}= \boxed{{\color{blue}{@total_surface_area@}}\, \text{cm}^2} \)

questionnote.text:
\(\text{The surface area of the rectangular part}= {@rect_area@}\,\text{m}^2\)

\(\text{The surface area of the triangular part}= {@tri_area@}\,\text{m}^2\)

\(\text{The total surface area}= {@ total_surface_area@}\,\text{m}^2\)

questiondescription.text:
Henry Onyango

This is a question on a composite solid. The student is expected to understand the figure and calculate its surface area. The required parts are:
Surface area of the triangular part
The total surface area

The student should know that the total surface area is found by adding the areas of all visible faces, not by using \(\text{SA}=\text{base area} \times \text{height}\),which is for volume or lateral area in some cases.

Checks for Incorrectly Identifying the Slanted Side

truefeedback.text:
Nice work identifying that the prism has a slanted rectangular face—recognizing that is important. However, it looks like the length you used for the slanted edge came directly from one of the triangle’s sides, rather than being calculated.

Since the triangular base is a right-angled triangle, you can find the slanted edge (the hypotenuse) using the Pythagorean theorem: \(\sqrt{{@b@}^2 \times {@h@}^2}=\text{hyp}\)

This gives you the correct length for that side of the rectangle. You're definitely on the right track—just remember to check whether any side lengths need to be worked out before using them.

node.description: Checks for the correct area of the triangular part.
Checks for Forgetting to Multiply by 2 for the Triangular Faces

truefeedback.text:
Great job calculating the area of one triangle correctly! You used the right formula and applied the base and height values well. That shows a good understanding of triangle area.

Just a small oversight: since the prism has two triangular faces, you need to multiply the area of one triangle by 2 to get the total area of the triangular part.

So instead of just \({@tri_1@}\,\text{m}^2\), it should be: \( 2\times {@tri_1@}\)

Keep up the good work—double-checking how many faces are involved will help you catch these small details next time!
